p: Since proteomic, human genetic and network analysis all highlighted Gch1 as a strong candidate for further investigation in α-synucleinopathy we proceeded to functional testing. We first used transgenic RNAi to reduce Gch1 in our α-synuclein transgenic flies using the pan-neuronal nSyb-GAL4 driver. Neuronal knockdown of Gch1 using either of two independent RNAi lines enhanced the motor deficits caused by α-synuclein expression, as shown by climbing (Fig. 4b) and locomotor activity (Fig. 4c). We verified that each RNAi line effectively reduced Gch1 expression (Fig. 4d). Importantly, knocking down Gch1 with transgenic RNAi had no effect on locomotion in the absence of human α-synuclein expression (Fig. 4b, c), using these partial loss of function lines (Fig. 4d), or on the levels of transgenic human α-synuclein (Supplementary Fig. 4).
